Topic.Title: Dialog with Sybil

Message.Msg: "Syb, if they don't honor stock options they aren't going to pay off your short bet either." It will indeed be dicey az market ckt breakerz kick on and off, and on and off again, then back on, and brokerage housez raise "house" margin maintenance requirements from 30% equity to 70% equity. That being said ALL short bets will be honored az they are direct bets that would require markets to stay permenantly off in order to not get paid. Short betting iz not a leveraged derivative like an option. Their iz more share counts taken in a single day of optionz writing then their are total sharez available (naked option writing iz allowed and levered etfs do it), so when it comez time where ALL puts win, there will not be enough sharez available woefully fallz short of contracted amounts. The cboe optionz market will shut down and need to be sorted out, it will take yearz to do so, and the institutionz will get some compansation while retailerz get none but a 'class action' law suite where tgey make nothing but penniez of their initial bet from 5 yearz prior if they are lucky.

Message.Title: Cramer iz not a true ars clown - he just gets paid handsomely to be one
Message.Msg: True ars clownz are clueless az to what they do and therefor willfully or unwillfully get romped in the dumper. Cramer doez not fall into this catagory - he just gets paid to make retailerz the ars clownz of the financial world. Do you honestly think that cramer risks all hiz own money for a pumped up 3% upside with a less than 2 standard deviation risk of a 60% downside??? He did so once in 1999 and list hiz own hedge fund for it and waz forced to become a cnbc carnival barker to survive, but since that time he haz been given 15 yearz to fine tune the timing of hiz "charitable action trust fund" tradezto meet sec compliance while benefiting from hiz own well timed bellz and whistlez.

Topic.Title: Taxes Coming - Game Over

Message.Msg: Will not happen. Frankly, the first reform has to be elimination of welfare with workfare. We have to reestablish the work ethic of this country. Massive infrastructure upgrade could be accomplished by making folks work and upgrading skills. Unions will fight but tough chyt. There's so much to rebuild in this country its crazy (most muni water systems are a century old...). At the same time, a ANNUAL government wealth tax of 2% (which is less than WS takes every year) can/should be instituted to force each generation (including those born with a silver spoon) to actually add value to society could help finance a transformation to workfare, where we would actually all get value in terms of improved infrastructure and lower future cost of doing business. It would close the income/wealth gap, which will increase the velocity of money and address the liquidity trap (all the money/wealth is so concentrated that AD drops as money shift from those with higher MPC to lower MPC). Admittedly, above likely unpopular with all sides, which is why it may be flawed, but is likely a move in the right direction...

Topic.Title: Cramer just killed the mo-mo in AMZN...

Message.Msg: "He just said on CNBC that AMZN is n extremely expensive stock." I don't understand how that's a revelation. AMZN has been expensive for a long long time and it hasn't mattered, as shown from their earnings declining from $2.52 peak toward negative numbers the last few years, while the stock took off from $167 to over $350 in that time frame. It was expensive by most measures at $167 two years ago when anlaysts forecasted to grow earnings as topline scale increased. And that didn't matter either when it didn't happen. Which begs the question: is the market efficient or a bubble mechanism for the transfer to the wealthy? I vote the latter.

Topic.Title: Dialog with Sybil

Message.Msg: That is a very dire scenario. Even in the 1987 & 2008 crashes (&1929 crash, with OTC options), options were paid off. If they shut the regular options down, the market itself will shut down.

Topic.Title: under 350 eod ?

Topic.Title: Dialog with Sybil

Message.Msg: Now, there is one case where you might be correct here. If a market is temporarily closed in the economic scenario you suggest, past the point where an option expires, I suppose the option holder would lose. But I'm sure the lawyers would litigate this. That is why trade long term options--more likely that the option term will outlast any closure that you say could happen, if that were to ever occur. Not that I don't short too--but I don't like getting margin calls. I mean you were shorting Amazon at $220--so you must be constantly in and out and trying to scalp the small swings. Very nerveracking.

Message.Title: AMZN's Q3 revenue beat
Message.Msg: I wonder how much of the revenue beat was from the fees paid by new Prime members. Didn't Bezo claim a few million new members? That's a few hundred millions in fees. So AMZN didn't really beat revenue estimate by that much. These new members will cost AMZN dearly in future shipping costs.

Topic.Title: Going pear shaped

Message.Msg: NASDAQ options problems are an interesting development. I'm not familiar with a "pearshaped" chart though. I'm thinking tulip shaped chart due to this quarter!

Topic.Title: AMZN's Q3 revenue beat

Message.Msg: You are correct about prime fees already booked and obligation for free ship is future added cost. Q3 was also artificially propped up because they started counting ebooks as 100% revenue instead of just the 30% commission. That added hundreds of million "on paper" too.
